t: Proverbs 25
Similitudes, Instructions
These*p also are proverbs of Solomon which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transcribed.
It*pn is the glory of God to conceal a matter, But*ln the glory of kings is to search out a matter.
As*iln the heavens for height and the earth for depth, So*ln the heart of kings is unsearchable.
Take*ln away the dross from the silver, And*ln there comes out a vessel for the smith;
Take*ln away the wicked before the king, And*ln his throne will be established in righteousness.
Do*ln not claim honor in the presence of the king, And*ln do not stand in the place of great men;
For*ln it is better that it be said to you, “Come up here,” Than*ln for you to be placed lower in the presence of the prince, Whom*ln your eyes have seen.
Do*ln not go out hastily to argue your*i case;*i Otherwise,*ln what will you do in the end, When*ln your neighbor humiliates you?
Argue*ln your case with your neighbor, And*ln do not reveal the secret of another,
Or*ln he who hears it*i will reproach you, And*ln the evil report about you will not pass away.
Like*iln apples of gold in settings of silver Is*ln a word spoken in right circumstances.
Like*iln an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold Is*ln a wise reprover to a listening ear.
Like*ln the cold of snow in the time of harvest Is*ln a faithful messenger to those who send him, For*ln he refreshes the soul of his masters.
Like*iln clouds and wind without rain Is*ln a man who boasts of his gifts falsely.
By*ln forbearance a ruler may be persuaded, And*ln a soft tongue breaks the bone.
Have*ln you found honey? Eat only*i what you need, That*ln you not have it in excess and vomit it.
Let*ln your foot rarely be in your neighbor’s house, Or*ln he will become weary of you and hate you.
Like*iln a club and a sword and a sharp arrow Is*ln a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.
Like*iln a bad tooth and an unsteady foot Is*ln confidence in a faithless man in time of trouble.
Like*iln one who takes off a garment on a cold day, or*i like*i vinegar on soda, Is*ln he who sings songs to a troubled heart.
If*ln your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat; And*ln if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;
For*ln you will heap burning coals on his head, And*ln the Lord*s will reward you.
The*ln north wind brings forth rain, And*ln a backbiting tongue, an angry countenance.
It*ln is better to live in a corner of the roof Than*ln in a house shared with a contentious woman.
Like*iln cold water to a weary soul, So*ln is good news from a distant land.
Like*iln a trampled spring and a polluted well Is*ln a righteous man who gives way before the wicked.
It*ln is not good to eat much honey, Nor*ln is it glory to search out one’s own glory.
Like*iln a city that is broken into and*i without walls Is*ln a man who has no control over his spirit.
